awd_titl_txt: CyberTraining: CDL: iPDC - Summer Institute for Integrating Parallel and Distributed Computing in Introductory Programming Classes
awd_abstract_narration:
The computing landscape has been changed in recent years due to the pervasive shift to multicore and GPU-based computer architectures. The current and future generations of our computing workforce will require the acquisition of a broad parallel and distributed computing (PDC) skill set, to enable the effective utilization of existing and emerging computing devices and cyber infrastructures. The current undergraduate computer science (CS) and computing engineering (CE) curricula, in most cases, do not integrate PDC concepts as required topics. The overall goal of the project is to prepare CS, CE, and Engineering undergraduate students for their future careers in light of this technological shift towards parallelism by improving faculty expertise in PDC through a series of week-long training workshops and by providing them with the resources to integrate PDC topics into introductory programming classes. This will enable the future workforce to contribute effectively in the emerging technological ecosystem, promoting the progress of science and advancing the national health, prosperity and welfare, which serves the national interest, as stated by NSF's mission. 
Based on the training of the trainer model, this project will be conducting a series of week-long workshops for non PDC CS1 and CS2 instructors through whom the project will be able to reach a larger audience of CS and CE undergraduates. The project will leverage existing PDC educational resources to enact a two-phase plan.  The first phase is to conduct a preliminary planning workshop to plan and develop a faculty development workshop and the IPDC toolkit. The IPDC toolkit will be an all-inclusive resource repository for the easy integration of PDC topics in introductory programming class without much effort required from the instructor. In the second phase a series five training workshops will be conducted over three years. These intensive faculty development workshops will include: 1) introduction to PDC concepts, 2) developing parallel programs using libraries and tools like Open MP, Java, and Mat lab, 3) PDC concepts through unplugged activities, 4) hands-on programming modules, 5) access to tools and information beyond the scope of IPDC. Continuous improvement through assessment and evaluation will be an integral part of the project. The projects goal is to reach seventy-five faculty over 3 years period who in turn will introduce PDC concepts and topics to over four thousand undergraduates per year. The participants selected for the project will come from institutions primarily involved in teaching but lack research infrastructure and PDC resources. Beyond the NSF funding cycle, the project will continue to provide online faculty development workshops and mini-workshops, using the IPDC toolkit, at CS and CE education conferences.

por.por_cntn:
The computing landscape has been changed in recent years due to the pervasive shift to multicore and GPU-based computer architectures. The current and future generations of our computing workforce will require the acquisition of a broad parallel and distributed computing (PDC) skill set, to enable the effective utilization of existing and emerging computing devices and cyber infrastructures. The current undergraduate computer science (CS) and computing engineering (CE) curricula, in most cases, do not integrate PDC concepts as required topics. The overall goal of the project is to prepare CS, CE, and Engineering undergraduate students for their future careers in light of this technological shift towards parallelism by improving faculty expertise in PDC through a series of week-long training workshops and by providing them with the resources to integrate PDC topics into introductory programming classes. This will enable the future workforce to contribute effectively in the emerging technological ecosystem, promoting the progress of science and advancing the national health, prosperity and welfare, which serves the national interest, as stated by NSF's mission.

Intellectual Merit

Integration of PDC topics in the undergraduate curriculum has been recently recognized as vital to comprehensive CS education and some work has been done to develop a library of PDC resources that can be used acro{ss various CS courses. The iPDC effort provides the next essential step towards transforming CS education by allowing the organization of weeklong professional development workshops for instructors, arming them with PDC teaching resources and building a community of PDC educators. This will enable students to gain the essential knowledge to effectively use the emerging advanced CI.

Based on the training of the trainer model, this project conducted a series of week-long workshops for non PDC CS1 and CS2 instructors through whom the project was able to reach a larger audience of CS and CE undergraduates. The project leveraged existing PDC educational resources to enact a two-phase plan. The first phase conducted a preliminary planning workshop to plan and develop a faculty development workshop and the IPDC toolkit. The IPDC toolkit is an all-inclusive resource repository for the easy integration of PDC topics in introductory programming class without much effort required from the instructor. In the second phase a series of training workshops was conducted over the following years. Each of these intensive faculty development workshops included: 1) an introduction to PDC concepts, 2) tutorials on developing parallel programs using libraries and tools, including Open MP, Java, and Python, 3) PDC concepts through unplugged activities, 4) hands-on programming modules, 5) access to community tools and information beyond those created for iPDC. Continuous improvement through assessment and evaluation was an integral part of the project.

Broader Impact

This project fostered a PDC mindset in CS/CE/Engineering faculty and empowered them to include important PDC topics into introductory programming coursework. It is our belief trained and equipped faculty will transform PDC education and increase the number of undergraduate students who think parallel. In addition, this will provide CS graduates with the appropriate skill sets to meet the challenges of the emerging multicore-GPU based highly parallel computers of today, and tomorrow.

The project has conducted five faculty professional development workshops over the life of the project (one virtual workshop during 2020, one hybrid workshop during the reporting period, and three in-person workshops during 2018 and 2019). Through these workshops a total of seventy-eight faculty members from sixy-seven institutions have been trained to integrate PDC topics into their introductory classes. These faculty reported teaching about four thousand and five hundred students PDC topics as a result of attending these workshops. These numbers are most likely a major underestimate of the number of students reached for the following reasons: (1) Only fourty-seven of the sixty-three faculty members (75%) completed the follow up survey from which this data was gathered; (2) The faculty from previous years are most likely continued to include PDC in their courses; (3) Many of the faculty reported including additional PDC topics in upper division courses which were not included on the survey; (4) The surveys did not capture the impact of changes at the institution beyond the faculty attending the workshops that can be attributed to faculty participating in the project; and (5) Covid-19 impacted faculty’s teaching of these topics this year.

Many hands-on active learning modules (both plugged and unplugged) have been developed (including one unplugged during the reporting year). These modules have been used during the workshops and subsequently by the faculty participants at their home institutions. These modules are available to the community via project website (https://www.csc.tntech.edu/pdcincs/index.php/ipdc-modules/). 

The curriculum resources developed during this project that have been disseminated to workshop participants and to the greater CS educator communities through the project website, meetings, an invite talk and four publications.
